A speaker's forum held in
the L/V Room of Levering
Hall from 10:30 to 2:30 and a
student boycott of classes are
planned for Hopkins today as
part of 'Free Prisoners of Apartheid Day,' a protest that is occurring at college campuses nationwide in response to the
system of apartheid in South
Africa.
Organized at Hopkins by the
Black Student Union, the
forum and boycott of classes
are part of an effort to raise
student awareness of the plight
of victims of apartheid
reduce university investments in
companies that do business in
South Africa. In a show of support, the Student Council passed a
resolution two weeks ago urging students to participate in the

day's activities by boycotting
classes and attending the
forum.
The actions taken by SC in
calling for students to boycott
classes has been met with mixed student reactions. Among
them was the question of why
the forum couldn't be moved
back to the weekend.
In response to why a boycott
is necessary, Darryl Cook, BSU
president answers,"I think the
boycott will mobilize people.
Having a forum on the
weekend wouldn't have the
same impact." Cook emphasizes that Friday, Oct. 11, is
the national date for "Free
Prisoners of Apartheid Day."

test, don't miss class. But

Warlike at Symposium:

Pres. Reagan May Be MAD,But He's Not NUTS
by Jeff Horn
The 19th Annual Milton S.
Eisenhower Symposium entitled "Arms Control: Strategy
and Diplomacy" began Tuesday in Shriver Hall with George
McGovern, the former
Democratic Senator from
South Dakota and presidential
candidate and Ambassador
Paul Warnke, the chief
negotiator of the SALT II
treaty.
The Symposium is dedicated
to former Hopkins President
Emeritus Milton S. Eisenhower
who died in May. The lecture
series is the only "living
memorial" to Eisenhower said

Brad Marks, co-chairman of
the Symposium along with
Mike DeRosa.
During the course of this session called,"Arms Control, the
Answer," both men discussed
the current problems in arms
control such as the need for
Star Wars, President Reagan's
Strategic Defense Initiative
(SDI) to develop a defense
against nuclear missiles through
high technology. Another problem that drew comments from
both speakers was Soviet
Premier Mikhail S. Gorbachev's
offer to reduce their existing
nuclear weaponry by 50 percent
in exchange for a commitment
from the U.S. to stop the SDI

and reduce their weapons to the
same level.
McGovern and Warnke each
talked about the subjects that
concerned them the most.
McGovern restated his campaign themes of the nuclear
freeze and the cancellation of
the MX missile program. Warnke spoke of the stupidity of
the failure of the U.S. to ratify
the SALT II treaty, plus the
need for further arms control
agreements.
In honor of Milton
Eisenhower and his brother,
President Dwight Eisenhower,
McGovern said, "They are the
kind of men I admired."

VP Post Subject of Debate
After Frosh Primary Election
by Jon Stempel
A victory for Grace Kung in
the race for freshmen class
secretary and a controversy in
the race for the class's vicepresident marked Tuesday's
freshman elections.
Kung easily defeated her two
rivals for secretary, Marty
Oberle and Robert Schuster, by
capturing 257 votes, nearly
fifty-seven percent of the 454
ballots that freshmen cast.
In the race for vice-president,
according to Elections Committee Chairman Scott Turner,
candidate Cary Gross was
dissatisfied with the EC's
declaration of a run-off
because, while he did not
receive a majority of the votes
cast, he outpolled the other
candidate, Wayne Myslik,
204-120, and believes he deserves
.ed to win. Turner said that

Gross was planning to file a
protest to the EC.
Turner said that a candidate
must have received "a clear fifty percent plus one majority"
of the total number of votes
cast in order to win his race.
Because 454 votes were cast
for all offices except representative and 1,005 votes were cast
for representative, a candidate
for all offices except representative had to receive 228 votes
to win, while a representative
candidate had to receive 503
votes to win. An abstention, according to Turner, counted in
all races except the race for
representative as a vote cast.
Gross argued, "My immediate reaction was disbelief
because I was told by a member
of the Election Committee that
this would be the final election
for the vice-presidency. The
purpose for a primary in any

election for office is to narrow
the field of candidates to two.
"Although the rules say that
someone needs a fifty percent
plus one majority for him to
win in the primaries," continued Gross, "that rule was
obviously mandated for situations in which there are more
than two candidates. Common
sense would dictate that when
you have only two candidates
to begin with, only one election
is necessary."
Myslik contended, "Considering the validity of the rules
of the Elections Committee, I
feel it would be at this time
pointless to argue because-any
changes that would be made
could not affect an election that
has already taken place."
"As for Cary's protest,"
continued Myslik, "both Cary

What's Inside
Who says Hopkins students
don't do interesting things?
As part of a program for
Eagle Scouts, Douglas
Barnhart spent two-and-ahalf months in Antarctica last
year. For a story on his
adventures, see pg. 14.

But Barnhart isn't the only Hopkins student doing something
interesting—part-time student James Lucas runs a jewelry
business. And it's quite a business. Lucas spends about two
weekends every month travelling, hoping to expand his sales
base. For details, see pg. 14.
And current students aren't the only ones leading fascinating
lives—there are some alumni of interest as well. Free-lance rock
critic J. D. Considine, for example, has written for publications such as The Washington Post. For a story on Considine's
career, see pg. 17.

Student employment at
WJHU, the location of the
radio offices, and direction of
the 25,000 watt signal were
among the topics discussed by
David Creagh, executive director of WJHU, on Wednesday,
October 2 at a meeting held in
AMR I which was open to all
interested students.
The meeting began with a
short business presentation and
discussion by Creagh. This was
followed by a much longer session in which Creagh answered
questions about the station. A
main concern of many students
was that they would be passed
over for part-time positions due
to more qualified professional
applicants.
Creagh, however, feels that
listeners of a 25,000 watt station will not be interested in
listening to an announcer simply because he is a student.
Creagh said, "In order to run
such a large station efficiently
and productively, the best people for the job must be
chosen." There are, however, a
few part-time positions that will
be targeted toward students.
Creagh also feels that this
policy will not hurt the
students' position as "many
students and community people
who I have heard were extremely impressive."
The offices of WJHU will
most probably be at 2216 N.
Charles St, a two-story office
building in which the first and
possibly part of the second
story would be utilized by
WJHU. The location is excellent for the placement of a
microwave antenna, as well as
its accessibility to the bus lines

Study Reveals
Frosh Endure
Extra Stress
College Press Service—Students
entering school this fall will encounter stresses they've never
dealt with before, and will probably
endure
regular
"academic calendar of stress"
periods before they finish college, a new University of Utah
study reveals.
"Students are away from
home, many for the first time,
and dealing with pressures and
responsibilities they've never
had before," explains study coauthor Neal Whitman, a researcher with the university's
Family
Department
of
Planning.
At the same time, though,
students experience less serious
stress because they have greater
control over their lives than
their non-student peers in the
real world, according to the
summary study of over 150 major stress reports.
"Stress is directly related to
how much control you have
over your life," says Whitman.

by Jon Stempel
Nineteen freshman candidates for Student Council
positions participated in a candidates' forum held the night of
October 3 in AMR I.
After a brief introduction by
an Elections Committee
member, each candidate
delivered a brief speech to the
audience. Approximately fortyfive non-candidates attended
the meeting.
Presidential candidate Bruce
Howard said that the freshman
class "has a lot of power and
potential." He asserted that
when pass-fail grading ends for
the freshmen in January,
"that's when we will need a
true leader. I have a lot of
energy and want to use it for
the class."
candidate
Presidential
Robert E. Lee began his speech
with a poem about his candidacy and concluded by saying, "I'll try my darnedest to
make sure you have the best
time of your lives."
Vice-presidential candidate
Cary Gross stated that if he is
elected, his job would be to
direct campus social events and
be an officer for the entire
freshman class, not just its
more vocal members.
The other vice-presidential
candidate, Wayne Myslik, said,
"Creativity and ability to solve
problems are two of the most
important duties an officer
must have. We can work
together to the goals we want."
Grace Kung, the newly
elected
freshman
class
secretary, could not attend the
forum, but in her speech, read
by representative candidate
Susan Land, wrote, "We can
accomplish a great deal if we
have good leadership. Your
voice will be heard."
Treasurer candidate Anil
Nurty asserted, "Without
money, there's nothing our
class can do. We need a person
who is energetic and can make
as much money for the class as
possible. I feel I can raise this

Memorial Service
Honors Eisenhower
by. Jay Lechtman
A memorial convocation was
held last Monday in Shriver
Hall to "celebrate the life at
Hopkins of President Emeritus
Milton S. Eisenhower," who
died last spring. Guests and
speakers included current
University President Steven
Muller, Chairman of the Board
of Trustees George B.
Radcliffe, former Illinois
Senator Charles H. Percy, and
Milton Eisenhower, Jr.
of
spoke
Radcliffe
Eisenhower's relation to the
Hopkins Board of Trustees.
"Our perspectives were
enlightened by his common
sense," said Radcliffe, and he
quoted Eisenhower, who once
remarked, "never in my three
university presidencies have I
had a better relationship, or a
higher regard for any board
than at Johns Hopkins."
An audio-visual presentation, entitled Milton Stover
Eisenhower—A Tribute followed, recounting his life and accomplishments, and giving personal insights into the man as
well.
Following the presentation,
Muller said, "No recollection
of him should be so solemn as
to ignore his exuberance and his
zest for living." According to
Muller, Eisenhower considered
student education his "highest
priority," adding to intellectual
advancement the importance of
values such as "personal
character, integrity, and moral
vision." The door to his home
was always open while he was
president, and he was known to
give scholarship money out of
his own pocket.
Muller, who was entreated
by Eisenhower to come to the
university after his "second
coming" (as his return to the
presidency was nicknamed),
also spoke of Eisenhower's
legacy to the University. "For
Johns Hopkins, his memory

and achievement are as immortal as the University itself—his
memory of greatness is our present and future beacon."
Senator Percy then spoke on
"the most overlooked" aspect
of Eisenhower's career.
Eisenhower "wanted to be to
Public Education, specifically
Public Broadcasting, what
Carnegie was to Public
Libraries," Percy said. "Public
Broadcasting truly reflects
America at its best," Percy
said, "and it's fitting that as we
remember Milton Eisenhower,
Johns Hopkins University is
working to add a third public
broadcasting outlet[WJHU]to
the Baltimore area."
Milton Eisenhower, Jr., said
after the program, that he
"particularly enjoyed Senator
Percy's remarks, and, of
course, the film."

Pre-Med Advisor
Kris Ann Cappelluti

Ganesh Ramachandran

John Gryder of the Department of Chemistry who recently replaced Ruth ',eyes as Health Professions
Advisor.

John Gryder of the
Chemistry Department has
been appointed health professions advisor following the
resignation of Ruth Leys from
this post.
"Basically, I want to calm
the premeds down and convince
them that the best way to get into medical school is by taking
courses they enjoy," stated
Gryder.
"I want to convince the
entering student that he or she
doesn't have to be a science major to be a premed. There is
more than one way to prepare
for med school and the student
should major in whatever he or
s;ie enjoys and that med school
requirements can be fit into any
major," he commented when
asked about his goals and
future plans as premed advisor.

Gryder reasons that a
Hopkins premed student tends
to "put blinders on." This, he
claims, is a major problem at
J HU because the students take
a "unidimensional curriculum"
that may actually decrease their
chances of acceptance to
medical schools because they
no longer "stand out."
He feels students should take
a more well-rounded program
because once they decide to
earn an M.D., "their profession is still open because of the
many opportunities in the
medical field." He opines that
a student's curriculum should
reflect what type of doctor he
or she wishes to become.
Dr. Gryder has been a
member of the Hopkins faculty since 1949. He previously
served as premed advisor for
ten years before he accepted a
post as associate dean.

The Student Council passed
a resolution last Wednesday to
form an ad-hoc committee on
Funding for student activities,
which will "examine the extent
and distribution of funding [as
well as] the sources of
funding."
The resolution, which was
passed by a vote of 9-2-2, was
proposed by Senior Class
Representative Alison Little.
She explained that in the past,
each class was budgeted several
thousand dollars for programming, but since the HOP now
organizes the majority of the
programming events, classes
don't use much money until
senior year. "Funding doesn't
seem to reflect the change in
programming," she said.
Treasurer Alan Rebenstock
stated that under the current
system, the SAC board decides
on what it feels is an appropriate amount for class expenditure, and if a class president submits a budget that is
less than or equal to this figure,
it will probably be approved.
However, several council
members raised the point that
many new programming expenses are not under the control
of the SAC. Included among
these are Spring Fair, Orientation, and athletic events supported by the classes. According to Rich Pan, a member of
the SAC committee, "There is
a need to investigate these other

expenses."
Former HOP chairman Mike
DeRosa also voiced concern
that the cost of providing entertainment is increasing faster
than the class budgets. "Going
away from beer programming,
you need good entertainment to
draw people to events," he
claimed. Sophomore Class
Representative Jenny Stahl

look to us for entertainment."
DeRosa said, "and it is a reflection of the university when people say the students can't bring
big names [to lecture] on
campus."

academics and student life. If

The Hopkins NewsoLetter Clearing Up Some
The Other Radio Station Confusion About
Everyone knows that WJHU is being
taken away from the students. But there
is also another campus radio station in
jeopardy: WA3EPT.
Most of you have probably never even
listened to WA3EPT. For those who
haven't, it is the station operated by the
Hopkins Amateur Radio Club. The club
provides students interested in ham radio
with hands-on experience. They are able
to contact other radio buffs throughout
the country and the world.
WA3EPT is in jeopardy because the
club's current building—the little shack
next to the Gatehouse—will soon be torn
down to make room for an expansion of
the Baltimore Museum of Art. The
university has agreed to let the museum
build a new sculpture garden in the small
dell behind the Gatehouse. The deal was
contingent upon the fact that this
newspaper be allowed to keep its offices
in the Gatehouse, but the radio club will
apparently be without a home.
We realize there is no way to
reasonably accomodate the radio shack
within the design of the sculpture garden,
and the club's 30-foot antenna currently located in the dell certainly can't stay.
Our point is that a greater effort should
certainly have been made to find a new

location for the radio club.
We know that won't be easy. The club
requires an office of some sort to store
its equipment, and needs to be near an
open area so antennae can be erected.
But saving an active student group ought
to be a high priority for the administration (particularly at a school not known
for active student groups).
Whether the university should have offered the land to the museum in the first
place is a debatable(and now academic)
question. Admittedly the area is currently ugly, but it is a wonderful location for
the radio club. Furthermore, it remains
to be explained what will be gained by
allowing the museum to use the area.
(Other, that is, than pleasing Robert and
Ryda Levi, whose sculpture will be placed in the garden, and who just happen
to give loads of money to both the school
and the museum.)
There is nothing wrong per se with
allowing the museum to use the dell. But
so far there has been little apparent effort to find a new location for the radio
club. And there is definitely something
wrong with disregarding student interests
because somebody in Garland Hall
decided to improve relations with the Art
Museum.

To Boycott...
Or Not to Boycott
What's going on here? Hopkins
students are concerned with Apartheid?
Some are even willing to miss classes for
it? Amazing. Rarely does anybody
around here look past the next orgo test.
But while it's certainly a blessing to see
students caring about something other
than their studies, it isn't at all clear just
what a boycott of classes today will
accomplish.
The issue of South Africa's institutional racism is, obviously, a complex
question deserving complex consideration. Should American institutions(most
definitely including this university) cease
to invest in that country? Is the current
government worse than whatever would
follow it, or is it better?(The latter is not
at all impossible. It was said for many
years that there could be nothing worse
than the Shah. We have something much
worse—the Ayatollah.) How will this
country's interests be best served?
The problem with a boycott is that it
will contribute nothing to a debate of
these issues. Instead, it will merely endorse a hopelessly vague assertion: Free
Prisoners of Apartheid. (The day has
been so designated by, among others, the
United Nations.)
If the boycott would actually accomplish something, we might be in
favor of it. Apartheid is clearly a barbaric system, and anyone unwilling to
voice his moral repugnance to it is either
blatantly misinformed or blatantly
stupid. But to merely say you are in favor
of freedom is to say something so bland
as to be uninteresting and unimportant.

Perhaps a worse problem with the
boycott, however, is that it reflects a
great moral asymmetry. There are literally dozens of countries around the world
which engage in heinous acts, which
persecute people for their race, their
religion, their political beliefs. Are we to
have boycotts about them all? Shall we
have a day to demand the release of
prisoners in the Soviet Union? Or Chile?
Or Cuba? Or North or South Korea? We
could probably make it through a whole
semester without ever going to a class.
It also ought to be noted, however,
that a strikingly large number of students
simply seem to have missed the point of
the boycott. They whine about the
sacrifice of missing one day of class, apparently unaware of the obscenity of objecting to such an inconvenience when
seeking to aid people living under tyranny. Can't they see that what happens in
South Africa is slightly more important
than getting a good grade in orgo lab?
No wonder Hopkins students are known
for being the finest examples of pre-med
syndrome.
Our objection to the boycott isn't that
it's invariably wrong to boycott classes,
it's that it will do little to better the situation in South Africa, or to further our
understanding of it. Such a protest ought
to accomplish something. Naively saying
that you're in favor of freeing the
prisoners of apartheid (who isn't?), particularly when you make no mention of
atrocities being committed elsewhere,
doesn't do anything constructive.

First, I would like'to clarify
all misconceptions about the
events taking place on Oct. 11,
1985, which has been
designated "Free Prisoners of
Apartheid Day." Most importantly, it should be noted that
the Black Student Union is petitioning, organizing and sponsoring the boycott and educational forums that will take
place Oct. 11, 1985. Moreover,

planned for the day. Indeed,
there are many students (that
have to go to class) who will be
making a stand against apartheid by participating in the
educational forums planned for
the day.
I am grateful that the Student
Council had the courage to take
a stand and come out and support the boycott. It is
disheartening to realize that

darrell edward cook

nation-wide event, in which

Second, there seems to be a

boycott. The purpose of the
boycott is simple—it is a means

the apathy that exists on this

serve as a thought-provoking

In reading last week's NewsLetter, I was shocked to
discover that many students

The first Antarctic stop was

seals and two species of
penguins there. He said he really enjoyed this brief stop,
because it is the only place these
animals exist on the continent.
"The penguins aren't at all
intimidated by humans," said
Barnhart. "In fact, they're
rather curious and friendly."
But apparently penguins give
off an odor of sulfur that can

be detected long before one can
see the nesting area.
"You could always tell when
someone had been around
penguins," said Barnhart.
The next and most important
stop was at McMurdo station,
where Barnhart would be doing
his experiments. McMurdo is
farther south along the coast,

and prepared them for experimentation. Barnhart did
not mind this at all because it

out the snowmobile."

the U.S. South Pole Station.

A thin, circular band of silver
hugs the underside of his wrist,
curls around the outer edges of
his arm, and snakes onto the
back of his hand, where the two

The bangle, designed and

James Lucas during his junior
year in high school, may someday take on a historic value to
match its aesthetic appeal. To
Lucas, a freelance designer and
entrepeneur, jewelry is a
serious, and growing, business.
"It all started in a crafts class
which I took in 9th grade," said
Lucas. "I decided I enjoyed
making things with my hands,
and I began to think about
designs for different things
which I could make. Eventually, I began to put some designs
which I had in my head, mostly for things like belt buckles,
onto paper. From there, all I

had to do was make them."
Although he enjoyed fashioning things in his crafts class, it
wasn't until later that his interest became a business. The
story of Lucas'jewelry business
is in a sense the quintessential
capitalist epic, the traditional
justification for free enterprise.
"My older sister is a fashion
commentator in New York. She
always liked buying elaborate
jewelry, and one day she came
home with a pair of earrings
which cost her some crazy

get organized."

"Because I'm a freelance

Ye Olde Record Reviews
by Peter Oehlkers
Marshall Crenshaw: Downtown (Warner Bros.)
In which Marshall scraps his
old band—his brother and a
friend—and gets some real
musicians behind him including
Tony Levin, Jerry Marotta,
and T-Bone Burnett (the
album's producer), to mixed
results. The production is the
best Marshall has ever gotten,
definitely, but makes him
sound just like any number of
"roots" bands currently clogging up the air at WHFS. This
record sits Marshall right along
side bands like the Blasters, Del
Fuegos, Jason and the Scorchers, and of course T-Bone
himself. That's all right but it
isn't really Marshall's natural
element. He's a pop songwriter, not a rock and roller.
Luckily, though, Marshall has
not lost any of his song-writing
skills—his gift for unpredictable phrasings is still intact—
so his songs stand out above all
the steel guitars and upright
basses. Except for the two
covers on the album--plodding
versions of "Right Now" and
"I'm Sorry (But So is Brenda
Lee)," which highlight Marshall's song- writing superiority and his real lack of "rockout-ability'—this is a very solid
album.
Del Fuegos: Boston, Mass.
(Slash/Warner Bros.)
Seeing that they're famous
now—their Miller Beer Commercial is still running—this
will probably be their last decent album and that's too bad.

Simply a rock band, nothing
more and nothing less. They
have discarded the country influences which mucked up their
debut album and have come
out rocking, although rocking
out at a much slower tempo
than in normal bands. They're
getting better in the songwriting
department but there is
something severly lacking in the
"freshness" department. Eventually they will probably sound
a lot like J. Geils. That's just a
prediction.
The Cure: The Head on the
Door (Electra/Asylum)
Robert Smith has taken a lot
of flack lately for ripping off
New Order on "In Between
Days," the album's single. On
the one hand, there is no doubt
that "In Between Days" is a
rip-off kind of a song. On the
other hand, the album and
single are pure Cure all the way
through—ripping off everyone
possible including themselves.
The result is a mish-mash of
contemporary electro-pop. It's
a progression from their last
album, The Top, but largely in
the same style—densely produced pop with a definite current of gloom running
throughout. Smith is an experimenter and there are a few
pleasant surprises on this
album—the piano- syncopated
"Six Different Ways" and the
pure synth-pop of "Close to
Me" but it's still fun to guess
which train Smith has jumped
on on each song—let's see,
"Push" is Ultravox, "Screw"
is Shriekback, etc. . . Still a
wonderful album—for those
without consciences. I happen

to love it.
Squeeze: Cosi Fan Tutui Frutti
(A&M)
Definitely not the same
Squeeze we knew and loved—
even with Jools Holland back.
A big mash of electronic, fake
funk, and convoluted songwriting. If you know
Squeeze—an entire album of
"F-Holes." Except for the bopping "King George Street" and
"Hits of the Year," there's no
pop left in the pop. Chris Difford still writes the best lyrics in
the business but this album is
mostly remarkable for its
grotesqueness. Laurie Latham,
over-producer, should be shot
for messing up this band.

Camper van Beethoven:
Telephone Free Landslide Victory (Independent Project)
Notable just for covering
Black Flag's "Wasted" using a
violin. The funniest, most
twisted album released so far
this year. The songs range from
the merely silly, "The Day That
Lassie Went to the Moon" to
the aggressively sarcastic,
"Where the Hell is Bill?"—
"Maybe he's gone to get a sideways haircut/Maybe he's gone
to go Mod Ska dancing" to the
downright savage attack on
suburban punks, "Club-Med
Sucks" and "I Hate Golf/I
Want to play Lacrosse." This
is not a punk album, per se.
fact, it's mostly acoustic, mostly instrumental, and the songs
are just plain good. Highest
Recommendation.

thoroughly enchanted the

Horszowski played the more
mirthful sections of the piece

full-bodied final measures and

meaningful
with the

The two final pieces on the

of Chopin. The second
Polanaise of Op. 40 embodies
a melody of blackness and morbidity, feelings which pervade
many of Chopin's works contemporary with this one.
Horszowski gave much grave
consideration to the dark
melody which opens the piece
and played with antipodal radiance the colorful, happy
melody which temporarily
gains the Polonaise after many
spirited musical battles with the
first theme. However, after a
final pitched battle of Olympian dimension in which
Horszowski capably portrayed
the essence of the contest between good and evil through
metaphor, the
melodic
Polonaise ends with the cryptic
melody once more dominating.
The enthusiasm of the
Shriver Hall audience enjoined
Mr. Horszowski to play an encore, and he gladly obliged with
Niendelssohn's Spring Songs
and Chopin's Op. 15, No. 2,
showing no fatigue in their
performance.
His program free from ostentation and pretentiousness, Mr.
Horszowski affirmed that his
true virtuosity lies in his unfeigned, yet sagacious, performing
style.
If Sunday evening's performance was any reflection at all
upon Mr. Horszowski's eightyseven years as a professional
pianist, the world has been truly
blessed with the simple honesty of this greatly accomplished
musician.

For most of us, there is no
reason or time between
alcoholism, classes and being
young to think of death. When
the thought does occur, it is a

JOHN NATHAN

joke, a silly abstract, a "slay"
on words—we've all died of
embarrassment, been killed by
tests, murdered by our
roommates—but in three
seconds we are resurrected an
go on in our immortal fashion.
To re,ad John Nathan's
Mishima: A Biography from
this youthful perspective is a
disorienting and eerie experience. Drawing from
Mishima's diaries and letters,
interviews with family and
friends, and his own personal
experience as Mishima's
translator(The Sailor who Fell
from Grace with the Sea) and
as his friend, Nathan has produced a morbidly fascinating
account of the Japanese
writer's lifelong obsession with
death. Published in 1974, the
book has been re-released to
coincide with the opening of the
movie Mishima by Paul
(American Gigilo,Taxi Driver)
Schrader.
Yukio Mishima, Japan's
most prominent postwar
novelist, was born in Tokyo on
January 14, 1925, and raised
until age twelve by his insane
grandmother. During what
Nathan depicts as a subnormal
childhood, he cultivated a penchant for "beauty, blood and
death" and developed a passion
for writing. At school
Mishima's subtly perverse fiction and poetry drew an admiring audience, and by sixteen he
had already been published in
a magazine. The advent of
World War 11 heightened his

desire for a "beautiful death,"
but he escaped the draft, being
declared physically unfit for duty. Mishima graduated with a
law degree from the Imperial
University in 1947 and soon absorbed himself completely in his
writing and his nihilistic fantasies. A three time contender
for the Nobel Prize, Mishima
was an extremely prolific and
versatile writer. He produced
forty novels, eighteen plays,
twenty volumes of short stories
and essays, and more than a
hundred romantice hack novels
for housewife consumption. By
the mid-1950's, he was a national celebrity and flamboyant
public figure. Like a displaced
American rocker, he sported
Hawaiian shirts, black pegged
pants, sunglasses and a crew
cut. He was open about his
homosexuality, but wed in
1958. He lifted weights
religiously and starred in a
gangster movie. In the 1960's
Mishima began to evolve a
"patriotism" that would provide him with the means and
faith to achieve "the rapture of
death," which he had sought
before all during his life in his
fantasies and his writing. Determined to became a man of action, he enlisted in Japan's Self
Defense Force in 1969 and soon
after formed his "Shield Society" to protect the emperor. On
November 20, 1970, after exhorting the troops of the self
Defense Force to rise up and
uphold the emperor, he reached the climax of his lifelong

obsession and committed seppuku (ritual suicide) in the Army headquarters.
Nathan's biography is a convincing, well-written analysis of
Mishima's complex desire to
die. He refutes the argument
that Mishima committed
suicide out of insanity,
masochism, or social protest—
and maintains that his seppuku
was the culmination of a
lifelong search in which "Beauty, Ecstasy and Death were
equivalent and stood for his
personal holy grail." Nathan
skillfully weaves throughout his
biography
selections from Mishima's
works that serve to support his
thesis. By the time the reader
reaches the end of the book,
and reads this passage from
Mishima's story "Patriotism,"
he can believe that the lieutenant committing suicide has
found "rapture":
So this was seppuku, he thought.
It was as if the sky had fallen on his
head and the world was reeling
drunkenly. the stomach, which had
thus far remained firm and compact,
now abiuptly heaved, opened wide
its wound, and the entrails burst
through.

Mishima is a compelling
work, not just for the scholar
or the confused moviegoer, but
for anyone adventurous enough
to enter into Mishima's dark
universe.

Record Climbs To 7-2

Hot Hooters Jolt Ursinus
by Mike Silverman
Having upset rival Ursinus
2-1 this past week, and achieving the status of a 7-2 record
and a ranking of seventh in the
eastern region division III soccer standings, the Hopkins soccer team has apparently "turned the corner" amidst its
playoff march.
Last Saturday, the Jays edged MAC division power Ursinus 2-1 in what has to be considered the squad's biggest win
in many years. Although outshot 15-12, the team held strong
on defense and thwarted a potent Badger attack. Freshman
sweeper Matt Lawrence played
a particularly strong game,
making numerous clears in
critical situations. Sophomore

Grenville Jones turned in a
solid effort, using his playmaking skills to coordinate a persistent attack and keep pressure
off the defensive corps. Senior
captains Rob Nardino and Dan
Olszewski accounted for the
two Hooter scoring tallies,
while Junior goalkeeper Ray
Giuriceo made eight saves in
the contest to keep his goals
against average below one.
Head coach William Tierney
was obviously very pleased with
the play of this team and its
progress this season.
"This was definitely our biggest win in quite some time,"
the coach remarked. "Strong
teams like Ursinus are the ones
you have to beat in order to
have a successful season. We
hadn't beaten them in a long

time, so the victory was an
especially satisfying one."
Despite outshooting their opponent 7-5, the Blue Jays were
edged 1-0 by division II power
UMBC this past Wednesday.
The squad dominated the first
half of play but fell to defeat
with 15 minutes left in regulation time to a very formidable
team. Ray Giuriceo posted
three saves in this hard-fought
contest.
The Hooters continue their
playoff quest by tackling a
tough Dickinson team tonight
at 7:00 p.m. on Homewood
Field. The Jays next see action
on Wednesday evening against
archrival Western Maryland in
what should be another well attended home game.

After a sluggish start, the Netsters have begun to swing into form in their
1985 campaign. They recorded a dramatic 5-4 win over Mt. St. Mary's
this past week.

Netsters S lit Pair
by Hanmin Lee
Lack of consistency still
seems to be the main problem
for the lady Netsters as they
continued their up and down
play last week. It started well as
Hopkins edged a very tough
Mt. St. Mary's team, 5-4, but
ended on somewhat of a sour
note as the Jays lost to a much
weaker Catholic University
squad.
The away match against Mt.
St. Mary's proved to be what
coach Kay Fowler Dressler called "the highlight of the year so
far." The Jays played some
gutsy tennis to split the singles,
3-3. All three singles matches
won by Hopkins were 3-setters,
an indication of their mental
toughness. Kathy March won at
no. 2 4-6, 6-4, 6-3. FowlerDressler commented, "I told her
we needed a win before the
match and she got it. Kathy just
played really well."
Victories at singles also came
from no. 4 Monica Canilang
who posted a tough 7-6, 6-2, 7-6
win and Huong Pham who won
4-6, 6-3, 6-3. No. 1 Kay Nelson,
and no. 5 Brigid Joyce all lost
in straight sets.
Tied at 3-all, Hopkins needed to win 2 of 3 in doubles to
post its 4th victory. Nelson and

March won a key match at first
doubles, 6-4, 7-5, while Emmick
and Joyce dropped their no. 2
doubles match. Matches were
tied at 4-all and the outcome
hinged on no. 3 doubles.
Canilang and Pham would easily be winners. However, when
Canilang twisted her ankle, it
seemed that Hopkins would
have to default. But with tears
in her eyes, and tape on her
ankle, Canilang continued.
Canilang and Pham managed
to take the 2nd set 7-5, locking
up a win for the Jays.
In their next match, a home
contest against Catholic
University, the Jays played
uninspired tennis, perhaps a
result of a letdown after their
victory over Mt. St. Mary's.
One bright spot was the continued good play of Huong
Pham, who is still undefeated
on the year. The only other
winners were Captain Kay
Nelson at no. 1, and the first
doubles team of Nelson and
March.
The State Tournament is
tomorrow and Saturday, and a
rematch against Mt. St. Mary's
is likely. Coach Fowler-Dressler
has been pointing to this tournament all fall, and she hopes
that Hopkins will be able to win
its 4th straight state title.

by Laura Perlinn

Tom Barthel

Co-captain Carol Butterworth looks to stick the ball upfield in the
Hocksters big win over Hood on Tuesda)r.

The women's varsity field
hockey team finally 'clicked'
last week, trouncing Trinity and
Hood 7-2 and 3-0, respectively.
The only sad note was a disappointing 2-1 loss in double
overtime to Mt. St. Mary's.
The Trinity game was played
on a muddy field in a light rain,
but the Jays' spirits were soaring. Alicia Collins tallied the
first two goals of the game on
penalty strokes, after the Trinity goalkeeper twice fouled to
prevent Hopkins from scoring.
Heather Klink replied with a
hat trick, slamming the ball into the cage on three separate occasions. Kacie White and Jennifer Kenoian each added one
point for the Lady Jays. April
Savoye, Jackie Fatula, and

Kenoian all had assists. The
seven total goals broke
Hopkins' record for number of
goals scored in one game.
The team then traveled to
take on Mt. St. Mary's.
Hopkins got on the board first
with a goal from Collins midway through the first half. The
opponents tied it up in the second half and sent the game into overtime. After a scoreless
first overtime period, a second
ten minutes period was played,
in which Mt. St. Mary's grabbed the 2-1 lead it never lost.
Still, the hocksters played a
well-fought game with many
scoring opportunities.
On October 8, the Jays
avenged their loss to Mt. St.
Mary's by soundly defeating
Hood 3-0. The first two goals
were scored by April Savoye off

penalty corners. Patti Ordonez,
who had been psyched to score
all game, added an insurance
goal late in the second half. The
defense played an excellent
game, too, and with several
spectacular saves from goalie
Amy Zimmerman, held Hood
scoreless.
The hocksters' next game is
against UMBC and will be
played at 7:00 pm on Tuesday,
October 15, on Homewood
Field. The team ends their
regular season after two away
games at Haverford and
Georgetown. Hopkins will then
take on Goucher, Notre Dame,
Mt. St. Mary's, Hood, and
other rival area teams in the
Baltimore College Tournament, to be held at Goucher
College on October 26 and 27.

Memorial Service
Honors Eisenhower
by. Jay Lechtman
A memorial convocation was
held last Monday in Shriver
Hall to "celebrate the life at
Hopkins of President Emeritus
Milton S. Eisenhower," who
died last spring. Guests and
speakers included current
University President Steven
Muller, Chairman of the Board
of Trustees George B.
Radcliffe, former Illinois
Senator Charles H. Percy, and
Milton Eisenhower, Jr.
of
spoke
Radcliffe
Eisenhower's relation to the
Hopkins Board of Trustees.
"Our perspectives were
enlightened by his common
sense," said Radcliffe, and he
quoted Eisenhower, who once
remarked, "never in my three
university presidencies have I
had a better relationship, or a
higher regard for any board
than at Johns Hopkins."
An audio-visual presentation, entitled Milton Stover
Eisenhower—A Tribute followed, recounting his life and accomplishments, and giving personal insights into the man as
well.
Following the presentation,
Muller said, "No recollection
of him should be so solemn as
to ignore his exuberance and his
zest for living." According to
Muller, Eisenhower considered
student education his "highest
priority," adding to intellectual
advancement the importance of
values such as "personal
character, integrity, and moral
vision." The door to his home
was always open while he was
president, and he was known to
give scholarship money out of
his own pocket.
Muller, who was entreated
by Eisenhower to come to the
university after his "second
coming" (as his return to the
presidency was nicknamed),
also spoke of Eisenhower's
legacy to the University. "For
Johns Hopkins, his memory

and achievement are as immortal as the University itself—his
memory of greatness is our present and future beacon."
Senator Percy then spoke on
"the most overlooked" aspect
of Eisenhower's career.
Eisenhower "wanted to be to
Public Education, specifically
Public Broadcasting, what
Carnegie was to Public
Libraries," Percy said. "Public
Broadcasting truly reflects
America at its best," Percy
said, "and it's fitting that as we
remember Milton Eisenhower,
Johns Hopkins University is
working to add a third public
broadcasting outlet[WJHU]to
the Baltimore area."
Milton Eisenhower, Jr., said
after the program, that he
"particularly enjoyed Senator
Percy's remarks, and, of
course, the film."

John Gryder of the
Chemistry Department has
been appointed health professions advisor following the
resignation of Ruth Leys from
this post.
"Basically, I want to calm
the premeds down and convince
them that the best way to get into medical school is by taking
courses they enjoy," stated
Gryder.
"I want to convince the
entering student that he or she
doesn't have to be a science major to be a premed. There is
more than one way to prepare
for med school and the student
should major in whatever he or
s;ie enjoys and that med school
requirements can be fit into any
major," he commented when
asked about his goals and
future plans as premed advisor.

Gryder reasons that a
Hopkins premed student tends
to "put blinders on." This, he
claims, is a major problem at
J HU because the students take
a "unidimensional curriculum"
that may actually decrease their
chances of acceptance to
medical schools because they
no longer "stand out."
He feels students should take
a more well-rounded program
because once they decide to
earn an M.D., "their profession is still open because of the
many opportunities in the
medical field." He opines that
a student's curriculum should
reflect what type of doctor he
or she wishes to become.
Dr. Gryder has been a
member of the Hopkins faculty since 1949. He previously
served as premed advisor for
ten years before he accepted a
post as associate dean.

The Hopkins NewsoLetter Clearing Up Some
The Other Radio Station Confusion About
Everyone knows that WJHU is being
taken away from the students. But there
is also another campus radio station in
jeopardy: WA3EPT.
Most of you have probably never even
listened to WA3EPT. For those who
haven't, it is the station operated by the
Hopkins Amateur Radio Club. The club
provides students interested in ham radio
with hands-on experience. They are able
to contact other radio buffs throughout
the country and the world.
WA3EPT is in jeopardy because the
club's current building—the little shack
next to the Gatehouse—will soon be torn
down to make room for an expansion of
the Baltimore Museum of Art. The
university has agreed to let the museum
build a new sculpture garden in the small
dell behind the Gatehouse. The deal was
contingent upon the fact that this
newspaper be allowed to keep its offices
in the Gatehouse, but the radio club will
apparently be without a home.
We realize there is no way to
reasonably accomodate the radio shack
within the design of the sculpture garden,
and the club's 30-foot antenna currently located in the dell certainly can't stay.
Our point is that a greater effort should
certainly have been made to find a new

location for the radio club.
We know that won't be easy. The club
requires an office of some sort to store
its equipment, and needs to be near an
open area so antennae can be erected.
But saving an active student group ought
to be a high priority for the administration (particularly at a school not known
for active student groups).
Whether the university should have offered the land to the museum in the first
place is a debatable(and now academic)
question. Admittedly the area is currently ugly, but it is a wonderful location for
the radio club. Furthermore, it remains
to be explained what will be gained by
allowing the museum to use the area.
(Other, that is, than pleasing Robert and
Ryda Levi, whose sculpture will be placed in the garden, and who just happen
to give loads of money to both the school
and the museum.)
There is nothing wrong per se with
allowing the museum to use the dell. But
so far there has been little apparent effort to find a new location for the radio
club. And there is definitely something
wrong with disregarding student interests
because somebody in Garland Hall
decided to improve relations with the Art
Museum.

To Boycott...
Or Not to Boycott
What's going on here? Hopkins
students are concerned with Apartheid?
Some are even willing to miss classes for
it? Amazing. Rarely does anybody
around here look past the next orgo test.
But while it's certainly a blessing to see
students caring about something other
than their studies, it isn't at all clear just
what a boycott of classes today will
accomplish.
The issue of South Africa's institutional racism is, obviously, a complex
question deserving complex consideration. Should American institutions(most
definitely including this university) cease
to invest in that country? Is the current
government worse than whatever would
follow it, or is it better?(The latter is not
at all impossible. It was said for many
years that there could be nothing worse
than the Shah. We have something much
worse—the Ayatollah.) How will this
country's interests be best served?
The problem with a boycott is that it
will contribute nothing to a debate of
these issues. Instead, it will merely endorse a hopelessly vague assertion: Free
Prisoners of Apartheid. (The day has
been so designated by, among others, the
United Nations.)
If the boycott would actually accomplish something, we might be in
favor of it. Apartheid is clearly a barbaric system, and anyone unwilling to
voice his moral repugnance to it is either
blatantly misinformed or blatantly
stupid. But to merely say you are in favor
of freedom is to say something so bland
as to be uninteresting and unimportant.

Perhaps a worse problem with the
boycott, however, is that it reflects a
great moral asymmetry. There are literally dozens of countries around the world
which engage in heinous acts, which
persecute people for their race, their
religion, their political beliefs. Are we to
have boycotts about them all? Shall we
have a day to demand the release of
prisoners in the Soviet Union? Or Chile?
Or Cuba? Or North or South Korea? We
could probably make it through a whole
semester without ever going to a class.
It also ought to be noted, however,
that a strikingly large number of students
simply seem to have missed the point of
the boycott. They whine about the
sacrifice of missing one day of class, apparently unaware of the obscenity of objecting to such an inconvenience when
seeking to aid people living under tyranny. Can't they see that what happens in
South Africa is slightly more important
than getting a good grade in orgo lab?
No wonder Hopkins students are known
for being the finest examples of pre-med
syndrome.
Our objection to the boycott isn't that
it's invariably wrong to boycott classes,
it's that it will do little to better the situation in South Africa, or to further our
understanding of it. Such a protest ought
to accomplish something. Naively saying
that you're in favor of freeing the
prisoners of apartheid (who isn't?), particularly when you make no mention of
atrocities being committed elsewhere,
doesn't do anything constructive.

First, I would like'to clarify
all misconceptions about the
events taking place on Oct. 11,
1985, which has been
designated "Free Prisoners of
Apartheid Day." Most importantly, it should be noted that
the Black Student Union is petitioning, organizing and sponsoring the boycott and educational forums that will take
place Oct. 11, 1985. Moreover,

planned for the day. Indeed,
there are many students (that
have to go to class) who will be
making a stand against apartheid by participating in the
educational forums planned for
the day.
I am grateful that the Student
Council had the courage to take
a stand and come out and support the boycott. It is
disheartening to realize that

Everybody at Hopkins

Douglas Barnhart was a little
different—he went to Antarctica.
Barnhart was one of the six
Scout finalists to be chosen for
the journey. He left last
November and returned in
May. Approximately four and
a half of these months were
spent on board ship, a 400-foot
icebreaker. During the trip,
Barnhart held the status of
Officer-in-Training, which is
the equivalent of a senior at the
Coast Guard or Naval Academies. He learned how to
navigate, and served as a
delegate to the captain. He also
participated in on-board
oceanographic experiments.
The first Antarctic stop was
at the United States' Palmer
Station, on the peninsula. Barnnhart observed four species of
seals and two species of
penguins there. He said he really enjoyed this brief stop,
because it is the only place these
animals exist on the continent.
"The penguins aren't at all
intimidated by humans," said
Barnhart. "In fact, they're
rather curious and friendly."
But apparently penguins give
off an odor of sulfur that can

be detected long before one can
see the nesting area.
"You could always tell when
someone had been around
penguins," said Barnhart.
The next and most important
stop was at McMurdo station,
where Barnhart would be doing
his experiments. McMurdo is
farther south along the coast,
and has about 1000 people
there in the summer.(Remember that summer in the
Southern Hemisphere is our
winter.) Many people are in the
Navy; the rest are scientists or
contracted workers.
The main biology and
geology labs are located at

goes on there. Barnhart worked in a biochemistry lab, experimenting with anti-freeze
proteins in fish. His work had
an unusual twist to it—he actually caught the fish himself
and prepared them for experimentation. Barnhart did
not mind this at all because it
was "an opportunity to take
out the snowmobile."
Barnhart spent four days at
the U.S. South Pole Station.

there is weather research, and
Barnhart suspected that the
reasons the U.S. has chosen to
maintain a base there are more

A thin, circular band of silver
hugs the underside of his wrist,
curls around the outer edges of
his arm, and snakes onto the
back of his hand, where the two
round caps come to a point an
inch or so from each other. An
elaborate and delicate design
has been stamped into the
bright silver, showing the care
which went into its creation.
The bangle, designed and
made by Hopkins student
James Lucas during his junior
year in high school, may someday take on a historic value to
match its aesthetic appeal. To
Lucas, a freelance designer and
entrepeneur, jewelry is a
serious, and growing, business.
"It all started in a crafts class
which I took in 9th grade," said
Lucas. "I decided I enjoyed
making things with my hands,
and I began to think about
designs for different things
which I could make. Eventually, I began to put some designs
which I had in my head, mostly for things like belt buckles,
onto paper. From there, all I

had to do was make them."
Although he enjoyed fashioning things in his crafts class, it
wasn't until later that his interest became a business. The
story of Lucas'jewelry business
is in a sense the quintessential
capitalist epic, the traditional
justification for free enterprise.
"My older sister is a fashion
commentator in New York. She
always liked buying elaborate
jewelry, and one day she came
home with a pair of earrings
which cost her some crazy
amount of money. I told her
she was wasting her money,
that I could make a pair just as
good for a lot less. Well, inade
her a pair of earrings, and a few
of her friends asked her where
she got them. They asked for a
few pairs, then they told a few
friends, and after a while it
began to take up a lot of my
time. That's when I decided to
get organized."
As good as Lucas is as a
designer, it is his organizational
skills which turned the hobby
into a business. An uncle who
is a successful commercial artist
taught him the importance of

research and persistence, and
Lucas decided it was time to
move into the fine jewelry
market. He grew up in Bloomfield, New Jersey, not far from
New York, and it was to New
York that he had to go. The
center of the industry is on 47th
street in Manhattan, and Lucas
began making trips there to buy
the gold, silver, and brass which
would go into his creations.
"When I started to put
together a portfolio, it became
important to have a sense of
what people would be wearing
during a particular season. I
started to read a lot of high
fashion magazines, from which
I would get a general concept,
or a 'look'. Then I'd just think
of what would go with it, I'd
draw it, and I'd make it."
After a while, he'd made a
varied assortment of pieces,
ranging from bracelets to cufflinks and ear clips. While a
student at the University of
Miami, he met a designer who
began to use some of his belts.
Not long afterwards, he began
marketing in earnest.
"Because I'm a freelance

designer, I have to take the first
step in getting my stuff into a
store. When I see a store which
I thing will do a good job of
selling, and which will sell the
jewelry at the price it's worth,
I call and set up an appointment to have the buyer looker
everything over. Then, if they
like it, they'll place an order
for, say, a dozen pairs of earrings and a few of everything
else."
Part of Lucas' marketing
strategy is to associate his name
with his product. Everything he
makes bears his discreet initials,
and all store displays group his
work together as a special collection. He also keeps varying
his designs, and never produces
more than a few of each particular piece. Each piece is consequently more distinctive, and
Lucas' work remains that of an
artist and not someone with a
few designs trying to make a lot
of money fast.
Lucas transferred to Hopkins
this fall, after two and a half
years at Miami. Although he

reasons. "When I was at
Miami, I kept having to fly to
New York to get materials.
Baltimore/Washington is closer
to New York, and it's got a
more accessible jewelry market
than Miami. Also, the
academics are better, and that's
obviously important."

Ye Olde Record Reviews
by Peter Oehlkers
Marshall Crenshaw: Downtown (Warner Bros.)
In which Marshall scraps his
old band—his brother and a
friend—and gets some real
musicians behind him including
Tony Levin, Jerry Marotta,
and T-Bone Burnett (the
album's producer), to mixed
results. The production is the
best Marshall has ever gotten,
definitely, but makes him
sound just like any number of
"roots" bands currently clogging up the air at WHFS. This
record sits Marshall right along
side bands like the Blasters, Del
Fuegos, Jason and the Scorchers, and of course T-Bone
himself. That's all right but it
isn't really Marshall's natural
element. He's a pop songwriter, not a rock and roller.
Luckily, though, Marshall has
not lost any of his song-writing
skills—his gift for unpredictable phrasings is still intact—
so his songs stand out above all
the steel guitars and upright
basses. Except for the two
covers on the album--plodding
versions of "Right Now" and
"I'm Sorry (But So is Brenda
Lee)," which highlight Marshall's song- writing superiority and his real lack of "rockout-ability'—this is a very solid
album.
Del Fuegos: Boston, Mass.
(Slash/Warner Bros.)
Seeing that they're famous
now—their Miller Beer Commercial is still running—this
will probably be their last decent album and that's too bad.

Simply a rock band, nothing
more and nothing less. They
have discarded the country influences which mucked up their
debut album and have come
out rocking, although rocking
out at a much slower tempo
than in normal bands. They're
getting better in the songwriting
department but there is
something severly lacking in the
"freshness" department. Eventually they will probably sound
a lot like J. Geils. That's just a
prediction.
The Cure: The Head on the
Door (Electra/Asylum)
Robert Smith has taken a lot
of flack lately for ripping off
New Order on "In Between
Days," the album's single. On
the one hand, there is no doubt
that "In Between Days" is a
rip-off kind of a song. On the
other hand, the album and
single are pure Cure all the way
through—ripping off everyone
possible including themselves.
The result is a mish-mash of
contemporary electro-pop. It's
a progression from their last
album, The Top, but largely in
the same style—densely produced pop with a definite current of gloom running
throughout. Smith is an experimenter and there are a few
pleasant surprises on this
album—the piano- syncopated
"Six Different Ways" and the
pure synth-pop of "Close to
Me" but it's still fun to guess
which train Smith has jumped
on on each song—let's see,
"Push" is Ultravox, "Screw"
is Shriekback, etc. . . Still a
wonderful album—for those
without consciences. I happen

to love it.
Squeeze: Cosi Fan Tutui Frutti
(A&M)
Definitely not the same
Squeeze we knew and loved—
even with Jools Holland back.
A big mash of electronic, fake
funk, and convoluted songwriting. If you know
Squeeze—an entire album of
"F-Holes." Except for the bopping "King George Street" and
"Hits of the Year," there's no
pop left in the pop. Chris Difford still writes the best lyrics in
the business but this album is
mostly remarkable for its
grotesqueness. Laurie Latham,
over-producer, should be shot
for messing up this band.

Camper van Beethoven:
Telephone Free Landslide Victory (Independent Project)
Notable just for covering
Black Flag's "Wasted" using a
violin. The funniest, most
twisted album released so far
this year. The songs range from
the merely silly, "The Day That
Lassie Went to the Moon" to
the aggressively sarcastic,
"Where the Hell is Bill?"—
"Maybe he's gone to get a sideways haircut/Maybe he's gone
to go Mod Ska dancing" to the
downright savage attack on
suburban punks, "Club-Med
Sucks" and "I Hate Golf/I
Want to play Lacrosse." This
is not a punk album, per se.
fact, it's mostly acoustic, mostly instrumental, and the songs
are just plain good. Highest
Recommendation.

Mishima: A Biography. by

For most of us, there is no
reason or time between
alcoholism, classes and being
young to think of death. When
the thought does occur, it is a

RzTit144/
JOHN NATHAN

joke, a silly abstract, a "slay"
on words—we've all died of
embarrassment, been killed by
tests, murdered by our
roommates—but in three
seconds we are resurrected an
go on in our immortal fashion.
To re,ad John Nathan's
Mishima: A Biography from
this youthful perspective is a
disorienting and eerie experience. Drawing from
Mishima's diaries and letters,
interviews with family and
friends, and his own personal
experience as Mishima's
translator(The Sailor who Fell
from Grace with the Sea) and
as his friend, Nathan has produced a morbidly fascinating
account of the Japanese
writer's lifelong obsession with
death. Published in 1974, the
book has been re-released to
coincide with the opening of the
movie Mishima by Paul
(American Gigilo,Taxi Driver)
Schrader.
Yukio Mishima, Japan's
most prominent postwar
novelist, was born in Tokyo on
January 14, 1925, and raised
until age twelve by his insane
grandmother. During what
Nathan depicts as a subnormal
childhood, he cultivated a penchant for "beauty, blood and
death" and developed a passion
for writing. At school
Mishima's subtly perverse fiction and poetry drew an admiring audience, and by sixteen he
had already been published in
a magazine. The advent of
World War 11 heightened his

desire for a "beautiful death,"
but he escaped the draft, being
declared physically unfit for duty. Mishima graduated with a
law degree from the Imperial
University in 1947 and soon absorbed himself completely in his
writing and his nihilistic fantasies. A three time contender
for the Nobel Prize, Mishima
was an extremely prolific and
versatile writer. He produced
forty novels, eighteen plays,
twenty volumes of short stories
and essays, and more than a
hundred romantice hack novels
for housewife consumption. By
the mid-1950's, he was a national celebrity and flamboyant
public figure. Like a displaced
American rocker, he sported
Hawaiian shirts, black pegged
pants, sunglasses and a crew
cut. He was open about his
homosexuality, but wed in
1958. He lifted weights
religiously and starred in a
gangster movie. In the 1960's
Mishima began to evolve a
"patriotism" that would provide him with the means and
faith to achieve "the rapture of
death," which he had sought
before all during his life in his
fantasies and his writing. Determined to became a man of action, he enlisted in Japan's Self
Defense Force in 1969 and soon
after formed his "Shield Society" to protect the emperor. On
November 20, 1970, after exhorting the troops of the self
Defense Force to rise up and
uphold the emperor, he reached the climax of his lifelong

obsession and committed seppuku (ritual suicide) in the Army headquarters.
Nathan's biography is a convincing, well-written analysis of
Mishima's complex desire to
die. He refutes the argument
that Mishima committed
suicide out of insanity,
masochism, or social protest—
and maintains that his seppuku
was the culmination of a
lifelong search in which "Beauty, Ecstasy and Death were
equivalent and stood for his
personal holy grail." Nathan
skillfully weaves throughout his
biography
selections from Mishima's
works that serve to support his
thesis. By the time the reader
reaches the end of the book,
and reads this passage from
Mishima's story "Patriotism,"
he can believe that the lieutenant committing suicide has
found "rapture":
So this was seppuku, he thought.
It was as if the sky had fallen on his
head and the world was reeling
drunkenly. the stomach, which had
thus far remained firm and compact,
now abiuptly heaved, opened wide
its wound, and the entrails burst
through.

Mishima is a compelling
work, not just for the scholar
or the confused moviegoer, but
for anyone adventurous enough
to enter into Mishima's dark
universe.

The success of this treatment
relies on the ability of these antibodies to distinguish cancer

cells. When it encounters an antigen that is not native to the
organism, the antibody signals
other cells in the immune
system to enter and destroy the
invading cells.
Antigens in an organism change
as a fertilized ovum divides,
and grows into a fetus. As
billions of cells divide daily,
they become organized through
biochemical signals unique to
each organ. This process is called differentiation. In cancer,
certain antigens normally present only in the early stages of
development reappear in the
rapidly dividing tumor cells.

Hot Hooters Jolt Ursinus
by Mike Silverman
Having upset rival Ursinus
2-1 this past week, and achieving the status of a 7-2 record
and a ranking of seventh in the
eastern region division III soccer standings, the Hopkins soccer team has apparently "turned the corner" amidst its
playoff march.
Last Saturday, the Jays edged MAC division power Ursinus 2-1 in what has to be considered the squad's biggest win
in many years. Although outshot 15-12, the team held strong
on defense and thwarted a potent Badger attack. Freshman
sweeper Matt Lawrence played
a particularly strong game,
making numerous clears in
critical situations. Sophomore

Grenville Jones turned in a
solid effort, using his playmaking skills to coordinate a persistent attack and keep pressure
off the defensive corps. Senior
captains Rob Nardino and Dan
Olszewski accounted for the
two Hooter scoring tallies,
while Junior goalkeeper Ray
Giuriceo made eight saves in
the contest to keep his goals
against average below one.
Head coach William Tierney
was obviously very pleased with
the play of this team and its
progress this season.
"This was definitely our biggest win in quite some time,"
the coach remarked. "Strong
teams like Ursinus are the ones
you have to beat in order to
have a successful season. We
hadn't beaten them in a long

time, so the victory was an
especially satisfying one."
Despite outshooting their opponent 7-5, the Blue Jays were
edged 1-0 by division II power
UMBC this past Wednesday.
The squad dominated the first
half of play but fell to defeat
with 15 minutes left in regulation time to a very formidable
team. Ray Giuriceo posted
three saves in this hard-fought
contest.
The Hooters continue their
playoff quest by tackling a
tough Dickinson team tonight
at 7:00 p.m. on Homewood
Field. The Jays next see action
on Wednesday evening against
archrival Western Maryland in
what should be another well attended home game.

hockey team finally 'clicked'

games at Haverford and

College on October 26 and 27.

Internships in State and Local Government: The Curriculum for Political
Leadership is now accepting applications for the mini-semester and spring

working for a member of the Baltimore

local government. If you are interested
in seeing how a part of the political
process works, pick up an application
in room D-1, Shriver Hall (basement).
The application deadline is Fri., Nov.
1. For further info., contact Chuck
Pizer, Ext. 4617.
